description.narrative: 73 492 marginalised girls supported to transition (51 065 girls demonstrate learning; 38 950 transition into secondary schools or Community Based Education.

IGATE-Transition's vision is to set girls up for success in their transition to secondary school and to life by improving their learning, leadership and lifeskills in primary and beyond. The project aim to ensure that 73492 marginalised girls are well equipped for transition into life through fluency in literacy, numeracy and financial literacy and life skills.

The project seeks to achieve the following three major outcomes: Learning, Transition and Sustainability. To improve learning - the project will ensure girls and boys are not only enrolled in school but also attending and, developing their skills in literacy, numeracy, and financial literacy, raising their confidence and self-esteem, as well as creating an enabling environment where girls and boys feel safe and supported to pursue their education. The project seek to achieve its vision on learning by: a) deliver a whole school development programme ? improve teaching and learning in target schools b) provide accelerated learning through community based education, c) offer highly relevant life-skills and exposure to business and entrepreneurial skills d) build aspirations and life-skills opportunities for in- and out-of-school girls. Transition- the project will support marginalized girls and boys in their transition from primary to secondary education. In parallel, the project will introduce non-formal, community-based, post-primary learning opportunities providing second chance and relevant life skills education to the many girls and boys of secondary age who have dropped out or are at risk of dropping out before, in the transition to, or within secondary school given the supply side barriers to secondary education in marginalized communities. To develop sustainability, IGATE-T will deliver improvements in learning and transition by: a) increasing schools? and MoPSE capacity to manage and monitor effective learning, b) strengthening the linkages between and increasing engagement of existing successful community to constructively address negative behavioural practices toward girls? education.
